div1.p: A Bold Stroke for a Husband, A COMEDY, AS ACTED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL, IN COVENT GARDEN. By MRS. COWLEY.
LONDON: PRINTED BY M. SCOTT, CHANCERY-LANE, FOR T. EVANS, PATERNOSTER-ROW. MDCCLXXXIV.

lg.l: NOW, by my sanguine hopes, our author cries,
With expectation sparkling in her eyes,
There's nothing here should scare me that I see,
They all are saplings of the tough old tree:
Women, who wear Elysium in their look,
And men, unconquer'd as their native oak.
But yet a word or two I'll briefly say,
To prove we're right in naming of our play.
Of human conduct, in each varied scene,
Th' extreme succeeds beyond the patient mean;
If eminence in rank our bosoms fire,
If merit to preferment dare aspire,
Follow the active, not the formal part,
"And snatch a grace beyond the rules of art."
Bold Strokes, from bounding genius firmly struck,
Attract success, more than the turns of luck.
The bankrupt swindler, though to pay unable,
Oft mends his fortune by the E O table;
Or, failing there, he acts a braver part,
And takes a purse,—a Bold Stroke for the cart.
The gamester too forgets each tender tie,
And ventures his last guinea on a die,
'Till ruin'd, and repenting of the evil,
He hangs himself—a Bold Stroke for the Devil.
The fortune hunter sports a suit of lace,
In this a Count, a Lord in t'other place,
Success at length, begins his married life
At Gretna Green—a Bold Stroke for a Wife.
But are bold strokes to vicious men confin'd?
Does virtue lie inactive in the mind?
It cannot be, while England's genius breathes,
And many a brow is deck'd with laurel wreaths.
Bold strokes in war are England's greatest pride;
Think how a HOOD has liv'd, a MANNERS died!
Our play holds forth the conquest of a heart,
By one bold stroke of nature, not of art.
A female pen calls female virtue forth,
And fairly shews to man her sex's worth.
Could men but see what female sense can do,
How apt their wit, their constancy—how true;
In vain would rakes the married state revile,
Nor with the wanton, precious time beguile.
Such is our aim, to rectify the age,
By bringing rising follies on the stage;
Be then propitious, let our fears decrease,
While you, with plaudits, ratify the peace!

body.head: A Bold Stroke for a Husband.

div2.head: SCENE I.
div2.stage: Enter SANCHA from a House, she advances, then runs back, and beckons to PEDRO within.

sp.speaker: SANCHA.
sp.p: HIST! Pedro! Pedro!

There he is: do'st see him? just turning by St. Antony in the corner. Now, do you tell him that your mistress is not at home; and if his jealous Donship should insist on searching the house, as he did yesterday, say that somebody is ill—the black has got a fever, or that—

sp.speaker: PED.
sp.p: Pho, pho, get you in. Don't I know that the duty of a iacquey in Madrid is to lie with a good grace? I have been studying it now for a whole week, and I'll defy Don or Devil to surprize me into a truth. Get you in, I say—here he comes.
Donna Laura is not at home, Sir.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Not at home!—come, Sir, what have you received for telling that lie?

sp.speaker: PED.
sp.p: Lie!—Lie!—Signor!—

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: It must be a lie by your promptness in delivering it.—What a fool does your mistress trust!—A clever rascal would have waited my approach, and, delivering the message with easy coolness, deceived me—thou hast been on the watch, and runnest towards me with a face of stupid importance, bawling, that she may hear through the lettice how well thou obeyest her,—"Donna Laura is not at home, Sir."

sp.speaker: PED.
sp.p: Hear through the lettice—hah! by'r lady she must have long ears, to reach from the grotto in the garden to the street.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Hah! [seizes him] Now, Sir, your ears shall be longer, if you do not tell me who is with her in the grotto.

sp.speaker: PED.
sp.p: In the grotto, Sir!—did I say any thing about the grotto? I—I only meant that—

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Fool!—dost thou trifle with me? who is with her?

sp.speaker: PED.
sp.p: Oh!—why nobody, Sir—only the pretty young gentleman's valet, waiting for an answer to a letter he brought. There! I have saved my ears at the expence of my place. I have worn this fine coat but a week, and I shall be sent back to Segovia for not being able to lie, though I have been learning the art six days and nights.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Well—come this way—if thou wilt promise to be faithful to me, I will not betray thee: nor at present enter the house.

sp.speaker: PED.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, blessings on you!

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: How often does the pretty young gentleman visit her?

sp.speaker: PED.
sp.p: Every day, Sir—If he misses, madam's stark wild.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Where does he live?

sp.speaker: PED.
sp.p: Truly, I know not, Sir.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: PED.
sp.p: By the honesty of my mother, I cannot tell, Sir. She calls him Florio;—that's his Christian name—his Heathen name I never heard.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: You must acquaint me when they are next together.

sp.speaker: PED.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, if there should be any blood spilt!

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Promise,—or I'll lead thee by the ears to the grotto.

sp.speaker: PED.
sp.p: I promise, I promise.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: There, take that, [gives money] and if thou art faithful I'll treble it. Now go in, and be a good lad—and, d'ye hear?—you may tell lies to every body else, but remember you must always speak truth to me.

sp.speaker: PED.
sp.p: I will, Sir,—I will.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: 'Tis well my passion is extinguished, for I can now act with coolness; I'll wait patiently for the hour of their security, and take them in the softest moments of their love. But if ever I trust to woman more—may every—

div2.stage: Enter two women, veiled, followed by JULIO.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Fye, ladies! keep your curtains drawn so late! The sun is up—'tis time to look abroad— [tries to remove their veils] Nay, if you are determined on night and silence, I take my leave. A woman without prattle, is like Burgundy without spirit.—Bright eyes, to touch me, must belong to sweet tongues.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Sure 'tis Julio. Hey!

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Don Carlos? Yes, by all the sober gods of matrimony!—Why, what business, goodman gravity, can'st thou have in Madrid—I understand you are married—quietly settled in your own pastures—father of a family, and the instructive companion of country vine dressers—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: 'Tis false, by heaven!—I have forsworn the country—left my family, and run away from my wife.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Really! then matrimony has not totally destroyed thy free will.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: 'Tis with difficulty I have preserv'd it though; for women, thou knowest, are most unreasonable beings! as soon as I had exhausted my stock of love tales, which, with management, lasted beyond the honey-moon, madam grew sullen,—I found home dull, and amused myself with the pretty peasants of the neighbourhood—Worse and worse!—we had nothing now but faintings, tears and hysterics for twenty-four honey-moons more.—So one morning I gave her in her sleep a farewell kiss, to comfort her when she should awake, and posted to Madrid; where, if it was not for the remembrance of the clog at my heel, I should bound o'er the regions of pleasure, with more spirit than a young Arabian on his mountains.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Do you find this clog no hindrance in affairs of gallantry?

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Not much.—In that house there—but, d—her, she's persidious!—in that house is a woman of beauty, with pretensions to character and fortune, who devoted herself to my passion.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: If she's persidious, give her to the winds.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Ah, but there is a rub, Julio, I have been a sool—a woman's sool!—In a state of intoxication, she wheedled me, or rather cheated me, out of a settlement.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Pho! is that—

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Oh! but you know not its nature. A settlement of lands that both honour and gratitude ought to have preserved sacred from such base alienation.—In short, if I cannot recover them, I am a ruined man.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Nay, this seems a worse clog than t'other—Poor Carlos! so bewiv'd and be—

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Prithee have compassion.

div2.stage: Enter a Servant with a letter to Julio, he reads it, and then nods to the Servant, who exits.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: An appointment, I'll be sworn, by that air of mystery and satisfaction—come, be friendly, and communicate.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: You are married, Carlos;—that's all I have to say—you are married.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Pho, that's past long ago, and ought to be forgotten; but if a man does a foolish thing once, he'll hear of it all his life.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Aye, the time has been when thou might'st have been entrusted with such a dear secret,—when I might have opened the billet, and feasted thee with the sweet meandring strokes at the bottom, which form her name, when—

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: What, 'tis from a woman then?

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Handsome?

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Hum—not absolutely handsome, but she'll pass, with one who has not had his taste spoilt by—matrimony.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Malicious dog!—Is she young?

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Under twenty—fair complexion, azure eyes, red lips, teeth of pearl, polished neck, fine turn'd shape, graceful—

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Hold, Julio, if thou lov'st me!—Is it possible she can be so bewitching a creature?

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: 'Tis possible—though, to deal plainly, I never saw her; but I love my own pleasure so well, that I could fancy all that, and ten times more.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: What star does she inhabit?

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Irradiate thou should'st have said, after such a description—but, faith, I know not; my orders are to be in waiting at seven, at the Prado.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Prado!—hey!—gad! can't you take me with you? for though I have forsworn the sex myself, and have done with them for ever, yet I may be of use to you, you know.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Faith, I can't see that—however, as you are a poor woe-begone married mortal, I'll have compassion, and suffer thee to come.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Then I am a man again! Wife, avaunt!—mistress, farewell!—At seven you say?

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Exactly.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: I'll meet thee at Philippi!

div2.head: SCENE II.
div2.stage: A spacious Garden belonging to Don CAESAR.

sp.speaker: MIN.
sp.p: There, will that do? My lady sent me to make her up a nosegay; these orange flowers are delicious, and this rose, how sweet!

sp.speaker: INIS.
sp.p: Pho, what significs wearing sweets in her bosom, unless they would sweeten her manners?—'tis amazing you can be so much at your ease; one might think your lady's tongue was a lute, and her morning scolds an agreeable serenade.

sp.speaker: MIN.
sp.p: So they are—Custom you know. I have been used to her music now these two years, and I don't believe I could relish my breakfast without it.

sp.speaker: INIS.
sp.p: I would rather never break my fast, than do it on such terms. What a difference between your mistress and mine; Donna Victoria is as much too gentle, as her cousin is too harsh.

sp.speaker: MIN.
sp.p: Aye, and you see what she gets by it; had she been more spirited, perhaps her husband would not have forsaken her;—men enlisted under the matrimonial banner, like those under the King's, would be often tempted to run away from their colours, if fear did not keep them in dread of desertion.

sp.speaker: INIS.
sp.p: If making a husband afraid is the way to keep him faithful, I believe your lady will be the happiest wise in Spain.

sp.speaker: MIN.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! how people may be deceived!—nay, how people are deceived!—but time will discover all things.

sp.speaker: INIS.
sp.p: What! what is there a secret in the business, Minette? if there is, hang time! let's have it directly.

sp.speaker: MIN.
sp.p: Now, if I dar'd but tell ye—lud! how I could surprize ye!—

sp.speaker: INIS.
sp.p: Don't go.

sp.speaker: MIN.
sp.p: I must go; I am on the very brink of betraying my mistress,—I must leave you—mercy upon me!—it rises like new bread.

sp.speaker: INIS.
sp.p: I hope it will choak ye, if you stir 'till I know all.

sp.speaker: MIN.
sp.p: Will you never breathe a syllable?

sp.speaker: INIS.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: MIN.
sp.p: Will you strive to forget it the moment you have heard it?

sp.speaker: INIS.
sp.p: I'll swear to myself forty times a-day to forget it.

sp.speaker: MIN.
sp.p: You are sure you will not let me stir from this spot till you know the whole.

sp.speaker: INIS.
sp.p: Not as far as a thrush hops.

sp.speaker: MIN.
sp.p: So! now, then, in one word,—here it goes. Though every body supposes my lady an errant scold, she's no more a—

sp.speaker: Don CAESAR
sp.p: Out upon't! e—h—h!

sp.speaker: MIN.
sp.p: Oh, St. Jerome!—here is her father, and his privy counsellor, Gasper. I can never communicate a secret in quiet. Well! come to my chamber, for, now my hand's in, you shall have the whole.—I wou'd not keep it another day, to be confidant to an infanta.

sp.speaker: GASP.
sp.p: Take comfort, Sir; take comfort.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Take it!—why where the devil shall I find it! You may say, take physic Sir, or, take poison, Sir—they are to be had; but what signifies bidding me take comfort, when I can neither buy it, beg it, nor steal it?

sp.speaker: GASP.
sp.p: But patience will bring it, Sir.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: 'Tis false, sirrah.—Patience is a cheat, and the man that rank'd her with the cardinal virtues was a fool.—I have had patience at bed and board these three long years, but the comfort she promis'd, has never called in with a civil how d'ye.

sp.speaker: GASP.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, but you know the poets say that the twin sister and companion of comfort is good humour.—Now if you would but drop that agreeable acidity, which is so conspicuous—

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Then let my daughter drop her perverse humour; 'tis a more certain bar to marriage than ugliness or folly; and will send me to my grave, at last, without male heirs. [crying.] How many have laid siege to her! But that humour of her's, like the works of Gibraltar, no Spaniard can find pregnable.

sp.speaker: GASP.
sp.p: Ay, well—Troy held out but ten years—Let her once tell over her beads, unmarried, at five-and-twenty, and, my life upon it, she ends the rosary, with a hearty prayer for a good husband.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: What, d'ye expect me to wait till the horrors of old maidenism frighten her into civility? No, no;—I'll shut her up in a convent, marry myself, and have heirs in spite of her. There's my neighbour Don Vasquez's daughter, she is but nineteen—

sp.speaker: GASP.
sp.p: The very step I was going to recommend, Sir. You are but a young gentleman of sixty-three, I take it; and a husband of sixty-three, who marries a wife of nineteen, will never want heirs, take my word for it.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: What! do you joke, sirrah?

sp.speaker: GASP.
sp.p: Oh no, Sir—not if you are serious. I think it would be one of the pleasantest things in the world—Madam would throw a new life into the family; and when you are above stairs in the gout, Sir, the music of her concerts, and the spirit of her converzationes would reach your sick bed, and be a thousand times more comforting then flannels and panada.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Come, come, I understand ye.—But this daughter of mine—I shall give her but two chances more.—Don Garcia and Don Vincentio will both be here to-day, and if she plays over the old game, I'll marry to-morrow morning, if I hang myself the next.

sp.speaker: GASP.
sp.p: You decide right, Signor; at sixty-three the marriage noose and the hempen noose should always go together.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Why, you dog you, do you suppose—There's Don Garcia—there he is, coming through the portico. Run to my daughter, and bid her remember what I have said to her.

She has had her lesson—but another memento mayn't be amiss—a young slut!—pretty, and witty, and rich—a match for a prince, and yet—but hist!—Not a word to my young man, if I can but keep him in ignorance 'till he is married, he must make the best of his bargain afterwards, as other honest men have done before him.
Welcome, Don Garcia!—why you are rather before your time.

sp.speaker: GARC.
sp.p: Gallantry forbid that I should not, when a fair lady is concern'd. Should Donna Olivia welcome me as frankly as you do, I shall think I have been tardy.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: When you made your overtures, Signor, I understood it was from inclination to be allied to my family, not from a particular passion to my daughter. Have you ever seen her?

sp.speaker: GARC.
sp.p: But once—that transiently—yet sufficient to convince me that she is charming.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Why yes, tho' I say it, there are few prettier women in Madrid; and she has got enemies amongst her own sex accordingly. They pretend to say that—I say, Sir, they have reported that she is not bless'd with that kind of docility and gentleness that a—now, tho' she may not be so very placid, and insipid, as some young women, yet, upon the whole—

sp.speaker: GARC.
sp.p: Oh fye, Sir!—not a word—A beauty cannot be ill-temper'd; gratified vanity keeps her in good humour with herself, and every body about her.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Yes, as you say—vanity is a prodigious sweetner; and Olivia, considering how much she has been humoured, is as gentle and pliant as—

sp.speaker: MIN.
sp.p: Oh, Sir! shield me from my mistress—She is in one of her old tempers—the whole house is in an uproar.—I cannot support it!

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Hush!

sp.speaker: MIN.
sp.p: No, Sir, I can't hush—A saint could not bear it. I am tired of her tyranny, and must quit her service.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Then quit it in a moment—go to my steward, and receive your wages—go—begone! 'Tis a cousin of my daughter's she is speaking of.

sp.speaker: MIN.
sp.p: A cousin, Sir!—No, 'tis Donna Olivia, your daughter—my mistress. Oh, Sir! you seem to be a sweet tender-hearted young gentleman—'twould move you to pity if—

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: I'll move you, hussey, to some purpose, if you don't move off.

sp.speaker: GARC.
sp.p: I am really confounded—can the charming Olivia—

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Spite, Sir—meer malice! My daughter has refus'd her some cast gown, or some—

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Where is she!—Where is Minette?

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Oh 'tis all over!—the tempest is coming.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Oh, you vile creature!—to speak to me!—to answer me!—am I made to be answer'd?

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Daughter! Daughter!

div2.stage: [During the following conversation he shews the most anxious impatience.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Because I threw my work-bag at her, she had the insolence to complain; and, on my repeating it, said she would not bear it.—Servants chuse what they shall bear!

sp.speaker: MIN.
sp.p: When you are married, Ma'am, I hope your husband will bear your humour, less patiently than I have done.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: My husband!—dost think my husband shall contradict my will? Oh, I long to set a pattern to those milky wives, whose mean compliances degrade the sex.

sp.speaker: GARC.
sp.p: Opportune!

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: The only husband on record who knew how to treat a wife was Socrates; and tho' his lady was a Grecian, I have some reason to believe her descendants match'd into our family; and never shall my tame submission disgrace my ancestry.

sp.speaker: GARC.
sp.p: Heav'ns! why have you never curb'd this intemperate spirit, Don Caesar?

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Curb'd, Sir! talk thus to your groom—curbs and bridles for a woman's tongue!

sp.speaker: GARC.
sp.p: Not for your's, lady, truly! 'tis too late. But had the torrent, now so overbearing, been taken at its spring, it might have been stem'd, and turn'd in gentle streamlets at the master's pleasure.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: A mistake, friend!—my spirit, at its spring, was too powerful for any master.

sp.speaker: GARC.
sp.p: Indeed!—perhaps you may meet a Petruchio, gentle Catherine, yet.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: But no gentle Catherine will he find me, believe it.—Catherine! why she had not the spirit of a roasted chesnut—a few big words, an empty oath, and a seanty dinner, made her as submissive as a spaniel. My fire will not be so soon extinguished—it shall resist big words, oaths, and starving.

sp.speaker: MIN.
sp.p: I believe so indeed; help the poor gentleman, I say, to whose fate you fall.

sp.speaker: GARC.
sp.p: Don Caesar, adieu! My commiseration for your fate subdues the resentment I should otherwise feel at your endeavouring to deceive me into such a marriage.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Marriage! oh mercy!—Is this Don Garcia?

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Yes, termagant!

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: O, what a misfortune! Why did you not tell me it was the gentleman you design'd to marry me to? Oh, Sir! all that is past was in sport; a contrivance between my maid and me: I have no spirit at all—I am as patient as poverty.

sp.speaker: GARC.
sp.p:
This mask sits too ill on your features, fair lady: I have seen you without disguise, and rejoice in your ignorance of my name, since, but for
that, my peaceful home might have become the seat f perpetual discord.

sp.speaker: MIN.
sp.p: Aye, Sir, you would never have known what a quiet hour—

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Impertinence! Indeed, Sir, I can be as gentle and forbearing as a pet lamb.

sp.speaker: GARC.
sp.p: I cannot doubt it, Madam; the proofs of your placidity are very striking—But, adieu! though I shall pray for your conversion, rather than have the honour of it—I'd turn Dominican, and condemn myself to perpetual celibacy.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Now, hussey!—now, hussey!—what do you expect?

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Dear me! how can you be so unreasonable! did ever daughter do more to oblige a father! I absolutely begg'd the man to have me.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Yes, vixen! after you had made him detest ye; what, I suppose, he did not hit your fancy, madam; tho' there is not in all Spain a man of prettier conversation.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Yes, he has a very pretty kind of conversation; 'tis like a parenthesis.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Like a parenthesis!

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Yes, it might be all left out, and never miss'd. However, I thought him a modest kind of a well-meaning young man, and that he would make a pretty sort of a husband—for notwithstanding his blustering, had I been his wife, in three months he should have been as humble and complaisant as—

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Ay, there it is—there it is!—that spirit of yours, hussey, you can neither conquer nor conceal; but I'll find a way to tame it, I'll warrant me.

div2.stage: [Olivia and Minette follow him with their eyes, and then burst into a laugh.]

sp.speaker: MIN.
sp.p: Well, madam, I give you joy! had other ladies as much success in getting lovers, as you have in getting rid of yours, what contented faces we should see.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: But to what purpose do I get rid of them, whilst they rise in succession like monthly pinks? Was there ever any thing so provoking?—After some quiet, and believing the men had ceased to trouble themselves about me, no less than two proposals have been made to my inexorable father this very day—What will become of me?

sp.speaker: MIN.
sp.p: What shou'd become of you? You'll chuse one from the pair, I hope. Believe me, madam, the only way to get rid of the impertinence of lovers, is to take one, and make him a scare-crow to the rest.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Oh, but I cannot!—Invention assist me this one day!

sp.speaker: MIN.
sp.p: Upon my word, madam, invention owes you nothing; and I am afraid you can draw on that bank no longer.—You must trust to your established character of vixen.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: But that won't frighten 'em all, you know, tho' it did its business with sober Don Garcia. The brave General Antonio would have made a property of me, in spite of every thing, had I not luckily discovered his antipathy to cats, and so scar'd the hero, by pretending an immoderate passion for young kittens.

sp.speaker: MIN.
sp.p: Yes, but you was still harder push'd by the Castilian Count, and his engrav'd genealogy from Noah.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p:
Oh, he would have kept his post as immovably as the griffins at his gate, had I not very seriously imparted to him, that my mother's great uncle sold oranges in Arragon.
Ha! ha! ha! And my little delicate spark, who washes in rose-water, and has his bed strewed with violets, would never have dismissed himself, hadst thou not scented my mareschal powder with assag foetida.

sp.speaker: MIN.
sp.p: And pray, madam, if I may be so bold, who is the next gentleman?

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Oh, Don Vincentio, who distracts every body with his skill in music. He ought to be married to a Viol de Gamba. I bless my stars I have never yet had a miser in my list—on such a character all art would be lost, and nothing but an earthquake, to swallow up my estate, could save me.

sp.speaker: MIN.
sp.p: Well, if some one did but know, how happy would some one be, that for his sake—

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Now, don't be impertinent, Minette. You have several times attempted to slide yourself into a secret, which I am resolv'd to keep to myself. Continue faithful, and suppress your curiosity.

sp.speaker: MIN.
sp.p: Suppress my curiosity, madam!—why, I am a chambermaid, and a sorry one too, it should seem, to have been in your confidence two years, and never have got the master-secret yet. I never was six weeks in a family before, but I knew every secret they had in it for three generations; aye, and I'll know this too, or I'll blow up all her plans, and declare to the world that she is no more a vixen than other fine ladies—they have most of 'em a touch on't.

sp.speaker: CARLOS.
sp.p: NAY, Madam, you may as well stop here, for I'll follow you through every apartment, but I will be heard.

sp.speaker: LAU.
sp.p: This insolence is not to be endured; within my own walls to be thus—

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: The time has been, when within your walls I might be master.

sp.speaker: LAU.
sp.p: Yes, you were then master of my heart, that gave you a right which—

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: You have now transferred to another.

sp.speaker: LAU.
sp.p: Well, Sir!

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: "Well, Sir!"—Unblushing acknowledgment! False, fickle woman!

sp.speaker: LAU.
sp.p: Because I have luckily got the start of you; in a few weeks I should have been the accuser, and you the false and fickle.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: And to secure yourself from that disgrace, you prudently looked out in time for another lover.

sp.speaker: LAU.
sp.p: I can pardon your sneer, because you are mortified.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Mortified!

sp.speaker: LAU.
sp.p:
Yes, mortified to the soul. Carlos! I know your sex: the vainest female, in the hour of her exultation and power, is still out-done by man in vanity.—'Tis
more your ruling passion, than 'tis ours; and 'tis wounded vanity that makes you thus tremble with rage at being deserted.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Madam! Madam!

sp.speaker: LAU.
sp.p: This rage would have been all cool insolence, had I waited for your change—the crime which now appears so black in me. Then, whilst, with all my sex's weakness, I had knelt at your feet, and reproached you only with my tears; how composed would have been your feelings.—Scarcely would you have deigned to form a phrase of pity for me; perhaps have bid me forget a man no longer worthy my attachment, and recommended me to hartshorn and my women.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Has any hour since I have first known you, given you cause for such unjust—

sp.speaker: LAU.
sp.p: Yes, every hour—Now, Carlos, I bring thee to the test!—You saw, you lik'd, you lov'd me; was there no fond trusting woman whom you deserted to indulge the transient passion? Yes, one blest with beauty, gentleness and youth; one, who more than her own being lov'd thee, who made thee rich, and whom thou mad'st thy wife.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: My wife!—here's a turn! So to revenge the quarrels of my wife—

sp.speaker: LAU.
sp.p: No, do not mistake me—what I have done was merely to indulge myself, without more regard to your feelings, than you had to her's.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: And you dare avow to my face, that you have a passion for another?

sp.speaker: LAU.
sp.p: I do, and—for I am above disguise—I confess, so tender is my love for Florio, it has scarcely left a trace of that I once avow'd for Carlos.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Well, Madam, if I hear this without some sudden vengeance on the tongue which speaks it, thank the annihilation of that passion, whose remembrance is as dead in my bosom as in yours. Let us, however, part friends, and with a mutual acquittal of every obligation—so give up the settlement of that estate, which left me almost a beggar.

sp.speaker: LAU.
sp.p: Give it up!—ha, ha!—no, Carlos, you consign'd me that estate as a proof of love; do not imagine then, I'll give up the only part of our connection, of which I am not ashamed.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Base woman! you know 'twas not a voluntary gift—after having in vain practis'd on my fondness, whilst in a state of intoxication, you prevailed on me to sign the deed, which you had artfully prepar'd for the purpose—therefore, you must restore it.

sp.speaker: LAU.
sp.p: Never, never.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Ruin is in the word!—Call it back, Madam, or I'll be reveng'd on thee in thy heart's dearest object—thy minion Florio!—he shall not riot on my fortune.

sp.speaker: LAU.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Florio is safe—your lands are sold, and in another country we shall enjoy the blessing of thy fond passion, whilst that passion is indulging itself in hatred and execrations.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: My vengeance shall first fall on her. [following] No, he shall be the first victim, or 'twill be incomplete.—Reduc'd to poverty, I cannot live;—Oh, folly! where are now all the gilded prospects of my youth? Had I—but 'tis too late to look back,—remorse attends the past, and ruin!—ruin waits me in the future!

div2.head: SCENE II.
div2.stage: VICTORIA enters perusing a letter; enter OLIVIA.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: To be sure—if my father should enquire for me, tell him I am in Donna Victoria's apartment.—Smiling, I protest! my dear gloomy cousin, where have you purchased that sun-shiny look?

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: It is but April sunshine, I fear; but who could resist such a temptation to smile? a letter from Donna Laura, my husband's mistress, stiling me her dearest Florio! her life! her soul! and complaining of a twelve hours absence, as the bitterest misfortune.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! most doughty Don! pray let us see you in your feather and doublet; as a Cavaleiro, it seems, you are formidable. So suddenly to rob your husband of his charmer's heart! you must have us'd some witchery.

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: Yes, powerful witchery—the knowledge of my sex. Oh! did the men but know us, as well as we do ourselves;—but thank fate they do not, 'twould be dangerous.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: What, I suppose, you prais'd her understanding, was captivated by her wit, and absolutely struck dumb by the amazing beauties of—her mind.

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: Oh, no,—that's the mode prescribed by the Essayists on the female heart—ha, ha, ha!—Not a woman breathing, from fifteen to fifty, but would rather have a compliment to the tip of her ear, or the turn of her ancle, than a volume in praise of her intellects.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: So flattery then, is your boasted pill?

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: No, that's only the occasional gilding; but 'tis in vain to attempt a description of what changed its nature with every moment. I was now attentive—now gay—then tender—then careless. I strove rather to convince her that I was charming, than that I myself was charm'd; and when I saw love's arrow quivering in her heart, instead of falling at her feet, sung a triumphant air, and remember'd a sudden engagement.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Would you have done so, had you been a man?

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: Assuredly—knowing what I now do as a woman.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: But can all this be worth while, merely to rival a sickle husband with one woman, whilst he is setting his feather, perhaps, at half a score others?

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: To rival him was not my first motive. The Portugueze robbed me of his heart; I concluded she had fascinations which nature had denied to me; it was impossible to visit her as a woman; I, therefore, assumed the Cavalier to study her, that I might, if possible, be to my Carlos, all he found in her.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Pretty humble creature!

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: In this adventure I learnt more than I expected;—my (oh cruel!) my husband has given this woman an estate, almost all that his dissipations had left us.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: To make him more culpable, it was my estate, it was that fortune which my lavish love had made his, without securing it to my children.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: How could you be so improvident?

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: Alas! I trusted him with my heart, with my happiness, without restriction. Should I have shewn a greater solicitude for any thing, than for these?

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: The event proves that you should; but how can you be thus passive in your sorrow? since I had assum'd the man, I'd make him feel a man's resentment for such injuries.

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: Oh, Olivia! what resentment can I shew to him I have vow'd to honour, and whom, both my duty and my heart compel me yet to love?

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Why, really now, I think—positively, there's no thinking about it; 'tis among the arcana of the married life, I suppose.

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: You, who know me, can judge how I suffered in prosecuting my plan. I have thrown off the delicacy of sex; I have worn the mask of love to the destroyer of my peace—but the object is too great to be abandoned—nothing less than to save my husband from ruin, and to restore him, again a lover, to my faithful bosom.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Well, I confess, Victoria, I hardly know whether most to blame or praise you; but, with the rest of the world, I suppose, your success will determine me.

sp.speaker: GASP.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, are your wedding shoes ready?

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Insolence! . . . . I can scarcely ever keep up the vixen to this fellow.

sp.speaker: GASP.
sp.p: You'll want them, Ma'am, to morrow morning, that's all—so I came to prepare ye.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: I want wedding shoes to-morrow! if you are kept on water gruel 'till I marry, that plump face of yours will be chap-fall'n, I believe.

sp.speaker: GASP.
sp.p: Yes, truly, I believe so too. Lackaday, did you suppose I came to bring you news of your own wedding? no such glad tidings for you, lady, believe me.—You married! I am sure the man who ties himself to you, ought to be half a salamander, and able to live in fire.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: What marriage then is it, you do me the honour to inform me of?

sp.speaker: GASP.
sp.p: Why, your father's marriage. You'll have a mother-in-law to-morrow, and having, like a dutiful daughter, danced at the wedding, be immur'd in a convent for life.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Immur'd in a convent! then I'll raise sedition in the sisterhood, depose the abbess, and turn the confessor's chair to a go-cart.

sp.speaker: GASP.
sp.p: So the threat of the mother-in-law, which I thought would be worse than that of the abbess, does not frighten ye?

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: No, because my father dares not give me one.—Marry, without my consent! no, no, he'll never think of it, depend on't; however, lest the fit should grow strong upon him, I'll go and administer my volatiles to keep it under.

sp.speaker: GASP.
sp.p: Administer 'em cautiously then—too strong a dose of your volatiles would make the fit stubborn. Who'd think that pretty arch look belong'd to a termagant? what a pity! 'twould be worth a thousand ducats to cure her.

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: Has Inis told you I wanted to converse with you in private, Gasper?

sp.speaker: GASP.
sp.p: Oh, yes, madam, and I took particular notice that it was to be in private.—Sure, says I, Mrs. Inis, Madam Victoria has not taken a fancy to me, and is going to break her mind.

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: Whimsical! ha, ha! suppose I should, Gasper?

sp.speaker: GASP.
sp.p: Why, then, madam, I should say fortune had used you dev'lish scurvily, to give me a grey beard in a livery. I know well enough that some young ladies have given themselves to grey beards in a gilded coach, and others have run away with a handsome youth in worsted lace; they each had their apology; but if you run away with me—pardon me, madam, I could not stand the ridicule.

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: Oh, very well; but if you refuse to run away with me, will you do me another favour?

sp.speaker: GASP.
sp.p: Any thing you'll order, madam, except dancing a fandango.

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: You have seen my rich old uncle in the country?

sp.speaker: GASP.
sp.p: What, Don Sancho, who, with two-thirds of a century in his face, affects the misdemeanors of youth; hides his baldness with amber locks, and complains of the tooth-ache, to make you believe that the two rows of ivory he carries in his head, grew there.

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: Oh, you know him, I find; could you assume his character for an hour, and make love for him? you know it must be in the stile of King Roderigo the First.

sp.speaker: GASP.
sp.p: Hang it! I am rather too near his own age; to appear an old man with effect, one should not be above twenty; 'tis always so on the stage.

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: Pho! you might pass for Juan's grandson.

sp.speaker: GASP.
sp.p: Nay, if your ladyship condescends to flatter me, you have me.

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p:
Then sollow me, for Don Caesar, I hear, is approaching—in the garden I'll make you acquainted
with my plan, and impress on your mind every trait of my uncle's character. If you can hit him off, the arts of Laura shall be foil'd, and Carlos be again Victoria's.

div2.stage: Enter Don CAESAR, followed by OLIVIA.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: No, no, 'tis too late—no coaxings; I am resolv'd, I say.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: But it is not too late, and you shan't be resolv'd, I say. Indeed, now, I'll be upon my guard with the next Don—what's his name? not a trace of the Xantippe lest.—I'll study to be charming.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Nay, you need not study it, you are always charming enough, if you would but hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Do you think so? then to the next lover I won't open my lips; I'll answer every thing he says with a smile, and if he asks me to have him, drop a court'sey of thankfulness.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Pshaw! that's too much t'other way; you're always either above the mark or below it; you must talk, but talk with good humour. Can't you look gently and prettily, now, as I do? and say, "yes, Sir, and no, Sir; and 'tis very fine weather, Sir; and pray, Sir, were you at the ball last night? and I caught a sad cold the other evening; and, bless me! I hear Lucinda has run away with her footman, and Don Philip has married his housemaid."—That's the way agreeable ladies talk, you never hear any thing else.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Very true; and you shall see me as agreeable as the best of 'em, if you won't give me a mother-in-law to snub me, and set me tasks, and to take up all the fine apartments, and send up your poor little Livy to lodge next the stars.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Ha,—if thou wert but always thus soft and good-humour'd, no mother-in-law in Spain, though she brought the Castiles for her portion, should have power to snub thee. But, Livy, the trial's at hand, for at this moment do I expect Don Vincentio to visit you. He is but just returned from England, and, probably, has yet heard only of your beauty and fortune; I hope it is not from you he will learn the other part of your character.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: This moment expect him! two new lovers in a day?

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Beginning already, as I hope to live; aye, I see 'tis in vain; I'll send him an excuse, and marry Marcella before night.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Oh, no! upon my obedience, I promise to be just the soft civil creature you have described.

sp.speaker: SER.
sp.p: Don Vincentio is below, Sir.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: I'll wait upon him—well, go and collect all your smiles and your simpers, and remember all I have said to you;—be gentle, and talk pretty little small talk, d'ye hear, and if you please him, you shall have the portion of a Dutch burgomaster's daughter, and the pin-money of a princess, you jade you. I think at last I have done it; the fear of this mother-in-law will keep down the fiend in her, if any thing can.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p:
Hah! my poor father, your anxieties will never end 'till you bring Don Julio:—Command me to sacrifice my petulence, my liberty to him, and Iphigenia herself, could not be more obedient. But what shall I do with this Vincentio?—I fear he is so perfectly harmoniz'd, that to put him in an ill temper will be impracticable.—I
must try, however; if 'tis possible to find a discord in him, I'll touch the string.

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: Presto, presto, Signor! where is the Olivia?—not a moment to spare. I left off in all the fury of composition; minums and crotchets have been battling it through my head the whole day, and trying a semibreve in G sharp, has made me as flat as double F.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Sharp and flat!—trying a semibreve!—oh—gad, Sir! I had like not to have understood you; but a semibreve is something of a demi-culverin, I take it; and you have been practising the art military.

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: Art military!—what, Sir! are you unacquainted with music?

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Music! oh I ask pardon; then you are fond of music—'ware of discords.

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: Fond of it! devoted to it.—I compos'd a thing to-day in all the gusto of Sachini and the sweetness of Gluck. But this recrcant finger fails me in composing a passage in E, octave: if it does not gain more elastic vigour in a week, I shall be tempted to have it amputated, and supply the shake with a spring.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Mercy! amputate a finger to supply a shake!

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: Oh, that's a trifle in the road to reputation—to be talk'd of is the summum bonum of this life.—A young man of rank shou'd not glide through the world without a distinguish'd rage, or, as they call it in England—a hobby horse!

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: A hobby horse!

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: Yes; that is, every man of figure determines on setting out in life, in that land of liberty, in what line to ruin himself; and that choice is called his hobby horse. One, makes the turf his scene of action—another drives about tall phaetons to peep into their neighbour's garret windows; and a third rides his hobby horse in parliament, where it jerks him sometimes on one side, and sometimes on the other; sometimes in, and sometimes out, 'till at length he is jerk'd out of his honesty, and his constituents out of their freedom.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Aye!—Well, 'tis a wonder that with such sort of hobby horses as these they should still outride all the world to the goal of glory. I wish we had a few of 'em to jerk Spain into some consideration.

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: This is all cantable; nothing to do with the subject of the piece, which is Donna Olivia;—pray give me the key note to her heart.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Upon my word, Signor—to speak in your own phrase—I believe that note has never yet been sounded.—Ah! here she comes! look at her.—Isn't she a charming girl?

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: Touching! Musical I'll be sworn! her very air is harmonious!

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: I wish thou may'st find her tongue so.
sp.stage: Enter Olivia, court'seys profoundly to each.
sp.p: Daughter, receive Don Vincentio—his rank, fortune and merit, entitle him to be the heiress of a grandee; but he is contented to become my son-in-law, if you can please him.

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p:
Please me! she entrances me! Her presence
thrills me like a cadenza of Pachierotti's, and every nerve vibrates to the music of her looks.
sp.l: Oh how largetto is the heart,
That charms so forté can defy!
sp.p: Donna Olivia, will you be contented to receive me as a lover?

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—No, Sir.

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; no, Sir! bewitching timidity!

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, she's remarkably timid.—She's in the right cue, I see.

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: 'Tis clear you have never travell'd—I shall be delighted to shew you England.—You will there see how entirely timidity is banish'd the sex. You must affect a mark'd character, and maintain it at all hazards.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: 'Tis a very fine day, Sir.

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: I caught a sad cold the other evening.—Pray was you at the ball last night?

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: What ball, fair lady?

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Bless me! they say Lucinda has run away with her footman, and Don Philip has married his house-maid.—Now am I not very agreeable?

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Oh, such perverse obedience!

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: Really, Madam, I have not the honour to know Don Philip and Lucinda—nor am I happy enough entirely to comprehend you.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: No! I only meant to be agreeable—but perhaps you have no taste for pretty little small talk?

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: Pretty little small talk!

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: A mark'd character you admire; so do I; I doat on it.—I wou'd not resemble the rest of the world in any thing.

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: My taste to the fiftieth part of a crotchet!—We shall agree admirably when we are married.

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: And that will be unlike the rest of the world, and therefore charming.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: It will do! I have hit her humour at last—Why did'nt this young dog offer himself before?

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: I believe I have the honour to carry my taste that way farther than you, Don Vincentio. Pray now, what is your usual stile in living?

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: My winters I spend in Madrid, as other people do. My summers I drawl through at my castle—

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: As other people do!—and yet you pretend to taste and singularity, ha! ha! ha! Good Don Vincentio, never talk of a mark'd character again.—Go into the country in July to smell roses and woodbines, when every body regales on their fragrance! Now I wou'd rusticate only in winter, and my bleak castle shou'd be decorated with verdure and flowers, amidst the soft zephyrs of December.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Oh, she'll go too far!

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: On the leafless trees I wou'd hang green branches—the labour of silk worms, and therefore natural; whilst my rose shrubs and myrtles shou'd be scented by the first perfumers in Italy—Unnatural indeed, but therefore singular and striking.

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: Oh, charming!—You beat me where I thought myself the strongest.—Wou'd they but establish newspapers here, to paragraph our singularities, we shou'd be the most envied couple in Spain.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: By St. Anthony, he is as mad as she is.

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: What say you, Don Caesar? Olivia and her winter garden, and I and my music.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Music, did you say! Music! I am passionately fond of that!

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: She has sav'd my life—I thought she was going to knock down his hobby horse.

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: You enchant me! I have the finest band in Madrid—My first violin draws a longer bow than Giardini; my clarinets, my viol de gamba—Oh you shall have such concerts!

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Concerts! Pardon me there—My passion is a single instrument.

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: That's carrying singularity very far indeed! I love a crash; so does every body of taste.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: But my taste isn't like every body's—my nerves are so particularly fine, that more than one instrument overpowers them.

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: Pray tell me the name of that one: I am sure it must be the most elegant and captivating in the world.—I am impatient to know it.—We'll have no other instrument in Spain, and I will study to become its master, that I may woo you with its music. Charming Olivia! tell me, is it a harpsichord? a piano sorte? a pentachord? a harp?

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: You have it—you have it—a harp—yes, a Jew's harp, is to me the only instrument.—Are you not charm'd with the delightful h—u—m of its base! running on the ear like the distant rumble of a state coach? It presents the idea of vastness and importance to the mind. The moment you are its master—I'll give you my hand.

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: Da capo, Madam, da capo! a Jew's harp!!

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p:
Bless me, Sir, don't I tell you so? Violins chill me—clarinets by sympathy hurt my lungs; and, instead
of maintaining a band under my roof, I wou'd not keep a servant who knew a bassoon from a flute, or could tell whether he heard a jigg or a canzonetta.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Oh thou perverse one; you know you love concerts—you know you do!

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: I detest 'em! It's vulgar custom that attaches people to the sound of fifty different instruments at once; 'twould be as well to talk on the same subject in fifty different tongues. A band! 'tis a mere olio of sound; I'd rather listen to a three-string'd guittar, serenading a sempstress in some neighbouring garret.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Oh you!—Don Vincentio, this is nothing but perverseness—wicked perverseness.—Hussey!—didn't you shake when you mention'd a garret? didn't bread and water and a step mother come into your head at the same time?

sp.speaker: VINC.
sp.p: Piano, piano, good Sir! Spare yourself all farther trouble. Should the Princess of Guzzarat, and all her diamond mines, offer themselves, I wou'd not accept them in lieu of my band—a band that has half ruined me to collect.—I wou'd have allowed Donna Olivia a blooming garden in winter; I wou'd even have procur'd barrenness and snow for her in the dog-days;—but—to have my band insulted!—to have my knowledge in music slighted!—to be rous'd from all the energies of composition by the drone of a Jew's harp! I cannot breathe under the idea.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Then—then you refuse her, Sir?

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: I cannot use so harsh a word—I take my leave of the lady—Adieu, Madam—I leave you to enjoy your solos, whilst I fly to the raptures of a crash.

div2.stage: CAESAR goes up to her and looks her in the face; then goes off without speaking.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Mercy! that silent anger is terrifying—I read a young mother-in-law, and an old lady abbess, in every line of his face.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Well, you heard the whole, I suppose—heard poor unhappy me scorn'd and rejected.

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: I heard you in imminent danger; and expected Signor Da Capo wou'd have snapp'd you up, in spite of caprice and extravagance.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Oh they charm'd instead of scaring him.—I soon found that my only chance was to fall across his caprice.—Where is the philosopher who cou'd withstand that?

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: But what, my good cousin, does all this tend to?

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: I dare say you can guess.—Penelope had never cheated her lovers with a never-ending web, had she not had an Ulysses.

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: An Ulysses! what are you then married?

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: O, no, not yet!—but, believe me, my design is not to lead apes; nor is my heart an icicle.—If you choose to know more, put on your veil, and slip with me through the garden to the Prado.

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: I can't indeed.—I am this moment going to dress en homme, to visit the impatient Portuguese.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Send an excuse—for positively you go with me. Heaven and earth! I am going to meet a man!—whom I have been fool enough to dream and think of these two years, and I don't know that ever he thought of me in his life.

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: Two years discovering that?

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: He has been abroad. The only time I ever saw him was at the Dutchess of Medina's—there were a thousand people; and he was so elegant, so careless, so handsome!—In a word, though he set off for France the next morning, by some witchcraft or other, he has been before my eyes ever since.

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: Was the impression mutual?

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: He hardly notic'd me—I was then a bashful thing, just out of a convent, and shrunk from observation.

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: Why, I thought you were going to meet him?

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: To be sure—I sent him a command this morning to be at the Prado. I am determined to find out if his heart is engaged, and if it is—

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: You'll cross your arms, and crown your brow with willows.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: No, positively, not whilst we have myrtles.—I wou'd prefer Julio, 'tis true, to all his sex; but if he is stupid enough to be insensible to me, I shan't for that reason pine like a girl, on chalk and oatmeal.—No, no; in that case, I shall form a new plan, and treat my future lovers with more civility.

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: You are the only woman in love, I ever heard talk reasonably.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p:
Well, prepare for the Prado, and I'll give you a lesson against your days of widowhood. Don't you wish this the moment, Victoria? A pretty widow at four-and-twenty
has more subjects and a wider empire than the first monarch upon earth.—I long to see you in your weeds.

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: Never may you see them! Oh, Olivia!—my happiness, my life, depend on my husband. The fond hope of still being united to him, gives me spirits in my affliction, and enables me to support even the period of his neglect, with patience.

div2.head: SCENE I.
div2.stage: JULIO enters from a Garden Gate with precipitation; a Servant within fastens the Gate.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: YES, yes, bar the gate fast, Cerberus, lest some other curious traveller should stumble on your confines.—If ever I am so caught again—
sp.stage: GARCIA enters, going hastily across, JULIO seizes him.
sp.p: Don Garcia, never make love to a woman in a veil.

sp.speaker: GARC.
sp.p: Why so, prithee? Veils and secrecy are the chief ingredients in a Spanish amour; but in two years, Julio, thou art grown absolutely French.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: That may be; but if ever I trust to a veil again, may no lovely, blooming beauty ever trust me.—Why dost know I have been an hour at the feet of a creature whose first birth-day must have been kept the latter end of the last century, and whose trembling, weak voice, I mistook for the timid cadence of bashful fifteen!

sp.speaker: GARC.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!—What a happiness to have seen thee in thy raptures, petitioning for half a glance only, of the charms the envious veil conceal'd.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p:
Yes; and when she unveil'd her Gothic countenance, to render the thing compleatly ridiculous, she began moralizing; and positively would not let me out of the snare, 'till I had persuaded her she had work'd a conversion,
and that I'd never make love—but in an honest way again.

sp.speaker: GARC.
sp.p: Oh, that honest way of love-making is delightful, to be sure. I had a dose of it this morning; but happily the ladies have not yet learnt to veil their tempers, though they have their faces.

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: Julio! Garcia! congratulate me!—Such an escape!

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: What have you escap'd?

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: Matrimony.

sp.speaker: GARC.
sp.p: Nay, then our congratulations may be mutual.—I have had a matrimonial escape too, this very day. I was almost on the brink of the ceremony with the veriest Xantippe!

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: Oh, that was not my case—mine was a sweet creature, all elegance, all life.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Then where's the cause of congratulation?

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: Cause—why she's ignorant of music! prefers a jig to a canzonetta, and a Jew's harp to a pentachord.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Jews harp!—Pho, prithee.

sp.speaker: GARC.
sp.p: Had my nymph no other fault, I would pardon that, for she was lovely and rich.

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: Mine too was lovely and rich, and, I'll be sworn, as ignorant of scolding as of the gama;—but not to know music!—

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Gentle, lovely, and rich—and ignorant only of music?

sp.speaker: GARC.
sp.p: A venial crime indeed! if the sweet creature will marry me, she shall carry a Jew's harp always in he train, as a Scotch laird does his bagpipes. I wish you'd give me your interest.

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: Oh, most willingly, if thou hast so gross an inclination;—I'll name thee as a dull-soul'd, largo fellow, to her father, Don Caesar.

sp.speaker: GARC.
sp.p: Caesar! what Don Caesar?

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: De Zuniga.

sp.speaker: GARC.
sp.p: Impossible!

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: Oh, I'll answer for her mother. So much is De Zuniga her father, that he does not know a semibreve from a culverin.

sp.speaker: GARC.
sp.p: The name of the lady?

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: Olivia.

sp.speaker: GARC.
sp.p: Why you must be mad—that's my termagant.

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: Termagant!—ha! ha! ha! Thou hast certainly some vixen of a mistress, who infects thy ears towards the whole sex. Olivia is timid and elegant.

sp.speaker: GARC.
sp.p: By Juno, there never existed such a scold.

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: By Orpheus, there never was a gayer temper'd creature—Spirit enough to be charming, that's all. If she lov'd harmony, I'd marry her to morrow.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Ha, ha! what a ridiculous jangle! 'Tis evident you speak of two different women.

sp.speaker: GARC.
sp.p: I speak of Donna Olivio, heiress to Don Caesar de Zuniga.

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: I speak of the heiress of Dou Caesar de Zuniga, who is called Donna Olivia.

sp.speaker: GARC.
sp.p: Sir, I perceive you mean to insult me.

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: Your perceptions are very rapid, Sir—but if you chuse to think so, I'll settle that point with you immediately—But, for fear of consequences, I'll fly home, and add the last bar to my concerto, and then meet you where you please.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Pho! this is evidently misapprehension.—To clear the matter up, I'll visit the lady—if you'll introduce me, Vincentio;—but you shall both promise to be govern'd in this dispute by my decision.

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: I'll introduce you with joy, if you'll try to persuade her of the necessity of music, and the charms of harmony.

sp.speaker: GARC.
sp.p: Yes, she needs that—You'll find her all jar and discord.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Come, no more Garcia—thou art but a sort of a male vixen thyself.—Melodious Vincentio, when shall I expect you?

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: This evening.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Not this evening; I have engag'd to meet a goldfinch in a grove, then I shall have music, you rogue!

sp.speaker: VIN.
sp.p: It won't sing at night.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Then I'll talk to it till the morning, and hear it pour out its matins to the rising sun.—Call on me to-morrow, I'll then attend you to Donna Olivia, and declare faithfully the impression her character makes on me.—Come, Garcia, I must not leave you together, lest his crotchets and your minums, should fall into a crash of discords.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p:
All hail to the powers of Burgundy! Three flasks to my own share.—What sorrows can stand again three flasks of Burgundy? I was a damn'd melanchol sellow this morning, going to shoot myself to get rid of my troubles.—Where are my troubles now? Gone to the moon to look for my wits; and there, I hope, they'll remain
together, if one cannot come back without t'other.—But where is this indolent dog, Julio? He fit to receive appointments from ladies! Sure I have not miss'd the hour—No—but seven yet— [looking at his watch.]—Seven's the hour, by all the joys of Burgundy! The rogue must be here—let's reconnoitre.

div2.stage: Enter VICTORIA and OLIVIA, veil'd, from the top.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Positively, mine's a pretty spark, to let me be first at the place of appointment. I have half resolv'd to go home again to punish him.

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: I'll answer for its being but half a resolution—to make it entire would be to punish yourself.—There's a solitary man—Is not that he?

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: I think not.—If he'd please to turn his face this way—

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: That's impossible, while the loadstone is the other way.—He is looking at the woman in the next walk. Can't you disturb him?

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Oh! a frightful frog!

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: Heav'ns, 'tis my husband.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Your husband! Is that Don Carlos?

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: It is indeed.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Why really, now I see the man, I don't wonder that you are in no hurry for your weeds.—He is moving towards us.

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: I cannot speak to him, and yet my soul flies to meet him.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Pray, lady, what occasioned that pretty scream? I shrewdly suspect it was a trap.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: A trap! Ha! ha! ha!—a trap for you!

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Why not, Madam?—Zounds, a man six feet high, and three flasks of Burgundy in his head, is worth laying a trap for.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Yes, unless he happens to be trapp'd before.—'Tis about two years since you was caught, I take it—Do keep farther off!—Odious! a married man!

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: The devil! Is it posted under every saint in the street, that I am a married man?

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: No, you carry the marks about you; that rueful phiz could never belong to a batchelor.—Besides, there's an odd appearance on your temples—does your hat sit easily?

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: By all the thorns of matrimony, if—

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Poor man! how natural to swear by what one feels—but why were you in such haste to gather the thorns of matrimony? Bless us! had you but look'd about you a little, what a market might have been made of that fine, proper promising person of yours—

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Confound thee, confound thee! If thou art a wife, may thy husband plague thee with jealousies, and thou never be able to give him cause for them; and if thou art a maid, may'st thou be an old one! [Going, meets Julio.] Oh, Julio, look not that way; there's a tongue will stun thee.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Heav'n be prais'd! I love female prattle. A woman's tongue can never scare me.—Which of these two goldfinches makes the music?

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Oh, this is as silent as a turtle— [taking Victoria's hand.— only coos now and then.—Perhaps you don't hate a married man, sweet one?

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: You guess right; I love a married man.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Hah, say'st thou so! wilt thou love me?

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: Will you let me?

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Let thee, my charmer! how I'll cherish thee for't.—What would I not give for thy heart!

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: I demand a price that, perhaps, you cannot give—I ask unbounded love; but you have a wife.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: And, therefore, the readier to love every other woman;—'tis in your favour child.

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: Will you love me ever?

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Ever! yes ever, 'till we find each other dull company, and yawn, and talk of our neighbours for amusement.

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: Farewell! I suspected you to be a bad chapman, and that you would not reach my terms.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Nay, I'll come to your terms if I can;—but move this way;—I am fearful of that wood-pecker at your elbow—should she begin again, her noise will scare all the pretty loves that are playing about my heart. Don't turn your head towards them; if you like to listen to love tales, you'll meet fond pairs enough in this walk.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: I really believe, though you deny it, that you are my destiny—that is, you fated me hither.—See, is not this your mandate?

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Oh, delightful! the scrawl of some chambermaid, or, perhaps, of your valet to give you an air—what is it signed? Marriatornes? Tomasa? Sancha?

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Nay, now I am convinced the letter is yours, since you abuse it; so you may as well confess.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Suppose I should, you can't be sure that I do not deceive you.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: True; but there is one point in which I have made a vow not to be deceived; therefore, the preliminary is, that you throw off your veil.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: My veil!

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Positively! if you reject this article, our negociation ends.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: You have no right to offer articles, unless you own yourself conquered.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: I own myself willing to be conquer'd, and have, therefore, a right to make the best terms I can.—Do you accede to the demand?

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: You had better.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: I protest I will not.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: My life upon't I make you. Why, madam, how absurd this is—'tis reducing us to the situation of Pyramus and Thisbe, talking through a wall;—yet 'tis of no consequence, for I know your features, as well as though I saw 'em.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: How can that be?

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: I judge of what you hide, by what I see—I could draw your picture.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Charming! pray begin the portrait.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Imprimis, a broad high forehead, rounded at the top, like an old-fashion'd gateway.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Oh, horrid!

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Little grey eyes, a sharp nose, and hair, the colour of rusty prunella.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Odious!

sp.speaker: JULIO
sp.p: Pale cheeks, thin lips, and—

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Hold, hold, thou villifier. [throws off her veil, he sinks on one knee] There! yes, kneel in contrition for your malicious libel.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Say rather, in adoration.—What a charming creature!

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: So, now for lies on the other side.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: A forehead form'd by the Graces; hair, which Cupid would steal for his bow strings, were he not engag'd in shooting through those sparkling hazel circlets, which nature has given you for eyes; lips! that 'twere a sin to call so—they are fresh gather'd rose leaves, with the fragrant morning dew, still hanging on their rounded surface.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Is that extemporaneous, or ready cut, for every woman who takes off her veil to you.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: I believe 'tis not extemporaneous, for nature, when she finish'd you, form'd the sentiment in my heart, and there it has been hid, 'till you, for whom it was form'd, called it into words.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Suppose I should understand, from all this, that you have a mind to be in love with me; wouldn't you be finely caught?

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Charmingly caught! if you'll let me understand, at the same time, that you have a mind to be in love with me.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: In love with a man! heavens! I never lov'd any thing but a squirrel!

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Make me your squirrel—I'll put on your chain, and gambol and play for ever at your side.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: But suppose you should have a mind to break the chain?

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Then loosen it; for, if once that humour seizes me, restraint won't cure it.—Let me spring and bound at liberty, and when I return to my lovely mistress, tired of all but her, fasten me again to your girdle, and kiss me while you chide,

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: Your servant—to encourage you to leave me again.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: No, to make returning to you, the strongest attraction of my life.—Why are you silent?

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: I am debating whether to be pleased or displeased at what you have said.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: You shall know when I have determined. My friend and yours are approaching this way, and they must not be interrupted.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: 'Twou'd be barbarous—we'll retire as far off as you please.

sp.speaker: OLIV.
sp.p: But we retire separately, Sir,—that lady is a woman of honour, and this moment of the highest importance to her. You may, however, conduct me to the gate, on condition that you leave me instantly.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Leave her instantly—oh, then I know my cue.

div2.stage: Enter CARLOS, followed by VICTORIA, unveiled.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: My wife!

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: Oh, heavens! I will veil myself again. I will hide my face for ever from you, if you will still feast my ears with those soft vows, which a moment since you poured forth so eagerly.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: My wife!—making love to my own wife!

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: Why should one of the dearest moments of my life, be to you so displeasing.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: So, I am caught in this snare, by way of agreeable surprize, I suppose.

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: Wou'd you cou'd think it so.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: No, madam! by heav'n 'tis a surprize fatal to every hope with which you may have flattered yourself.—What am I to be followed, haunted, watched?

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p:
Not to upbraid you.—I follow'd you, because
my castle without you seem'd a dreary desart.—Indeed, I will never upbraid you.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Generous assurance!—never upbraid me—no by heavens, I'll take care you never shall.—She has touch'd my soul, but I dare not yield to the impression.—Her softness is worse than death to me.

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: Would I could find words to please you!

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: You cannot; therefore leave me, or suffer me to go without attempting to follow me.

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: Is it possible yoo can be so barbarous?

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Do not expostulate; your first vow'd duty is obedience—that word so grating to your sex.

sp.speaker: VICT.
sp.p: To me it was never grating—to obey you has been my joy; even now I will not dispute your will, though I feel, for the first time, obedience hateful. [going, and then turning back] Oh, Carlos! my dear Carlos! I go, but my soul remains with you.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Oh, horrible! had I not taken this harsh measure, I must have kill'd myself, for how could I tell her that I have made her a beggar? better she should hate, detest me! than that my tenderness should give her a prospect of felicity, which now she can never taste.—Oh, wine-created spirit! Where art thou now? Madness, return to me again; for reason presents me nothing but despair.

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p: Carlos, who the devil can they be? my charming little witch was inflexible.—I hope yours has been more communicative.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.p: Folly!—Nonsense!

sp.speaker: JULIO.
sp.p:
Folly!—Nonsense! What, a pretty woman's smile! ha, ha, ha! upon my soul it has more persuasion, and, consequently, more reason, than a logical disquisition
—but these married fellows have neither taste nor joy.—Humph—suppose my fair one should want to debase me into such an animal;—she can't have so much villainy in her disposition: and yet, if she should? pho! it won't bear thinking about.—If I do so mad a thing, it must be as cowards fight, without daring to reflect on the danger.

head.stage: an apartment in the House of Don VASQUEZ, MARCELLA's Father.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Well, Don Vasquez, and a—you—then I say, you have a mind that I should marry your daughter?

sp.speaker: VASQ.
sp.p: It is sufficient, Signor, that you have signified to us your intention—my daughter shall prove her gratitude, in her attention to your felicity.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Egad! now it comes to the push! [aside] hem, hem!—but just nineteen, you say.

sp.speaker: VASQ.
sp.p: Exactly, the eleventh of last month.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Pity it was not twenty.

sp.speaker: VASQ.
sp.p: Why a year can make no difference, I should think.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: O, yes it does; a year's great deal;—they are so skittish at nineteen.

sp.speaker: VASQ.
sp.p: Those who are skittish at nineteen, I fear, you won't find much mended at twenty. Marcella is very grave, and a pretty little, plump, fair—

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Aye, fair, again! pity she isn't brown or olive—I like your olives.

sp.speaker: VASQ.
sp.p: Brown and olive! you are very whimsical, my old friend.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p:
Why these fair girls are so stared at by the men, and the young fellows, now-a-days, have a damn'd impudent
stare with them,—'tis very abashing to a woman—very distressing!

sp.speaker: VASQ.
sp.p: Yes, so it is; but happily their distress is of that nature that it generally goes off in a simper. But come, I'll send Marcella to you, and she will—

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: No, no, stay my good friend. [gasping] You are in a violent hurry.

sp.speaker: VASQ
sp.p: Why, truly, Signor, at our time of life, when we determine to marry, we have no time to lose.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Why, that's very true, and so—oh! St. Anthony, now it comes to the point—but there can be no harm in looking at her—a look won't bind us for better for worse. [aside] Well then—if you have a mind, I say, you may let me see her.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: [Puts on his spectacles] Aye, here she comes—I hear her—trip, trip, trip! I don't like that step. A woman should always tread steadily, with dignity, it awes the men.

sp.speaker: VASQ.
sp.p: There, Marcella, behold your future husband; and remember that your kindness to him, will be the standard of your duty to me.

sp.speaker: MARC.
sp.p: Oh, heavens!

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Somehow I am afraid to look round.

sp.speaker: MARC.
sp.p: Surely he does not know that I am here!

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: So—she knows how to give an item, I find.

sp.speaker: MARC.
sp.p: Pray, Signor, have you any commands for me?

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Hum!—not non-plus'd at all. [looks around] Oh! that eye, I don't like that eye.

sp.speaker: MARC.
sp.p: My father commanded me—

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Yes, I know—I know. [to her] Why, now I look again, there is a sort of a modest.—Oh, that smile! that smile will never do.

sp.speaker: MARC.
sp.p: I understand, Signor, that you have demanded my hand in marriage.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Upon my word, plump to the point! [aside] Yes, I did a sort of—I can't say but that I did—

sp.speaker: MARC.
sp.p: I am not insensible of the honour you do me, Sir, but—but—

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: But!—What don't you like the thoughts of the match?

sp.speaker: MARC.
sp.p: Oh, yes, Sir, yes—exceedingly. I dare not say no.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Oh, you do—exceedingly! What, I suppose, child, your head is full of jewels, and finery, and equipage?

sp.speaker: MARC.
sp.p: No indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: No, what then? what sort of a life do you expect to lead when you are my wife? what pleasures d'ye look forward to?

sp.speaker: MARC.
sp.p: None!

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Hey!

sp.speaker: MARC.
sp.p: I shall obey my father, Sir; I shall marry you; but I shall be most wretched!

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: MARC.
sp.p: There is not a fate I would not prefer;—but pardon me!

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Go on, go on, I never was better pleas'd

sp.speaker: MARC.
sp.p: Pleas'd at my reluctance!

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Never, never better pleas'd in my life;—so you had really now, you young baggage, rather have me for a grandfather than a husband?

sp.speaker: MARC.
sp.p: Forgive my frankness, Sir,—a thousand times!

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: My dear girl, let me kiss your hand.—Egad! you've let me off charmingly. I was frightened out of my wits lest you should have taken as violent an inclination to the match, as your father has.

sp.speaker: MARC.
sp.p: Dear Sir, you charm me.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: But hark ye;—you'll certainly incur your father's anger, if I don't take the refusal entirely on myself, which I will do, if you'll only assist me in a little business I have in hand.

sp.speaker: MARC.
sp.p: Any thing to shew my gratitude.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: You must know, I can't get my daughter to marry—there's nothing on earth will drive her to it, but the dread of a mother in-law. Now, if you will let it appear to her, that you and I are driving to the goal of matrimony; I believe it will do—what say you? shall we be lovers in play?

sp.speaker: MARC.
sp.p: If you are sure it will be only in play.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Oh, my life upon't—but we must be very fond, you know.

sp.speaker: MARC.
sp.p: To be sure—exceedingly tender; ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: You must smile upon me now and then roguishly; and slide your hand into mine, when you are sure she secs you, and let me pat your cheek, and—

sp.speaker: MARC.
sp.p: Oh, no farther pray—that will be quite sussicient.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Gad, I begin to take a fancy to your rogue's face, now I'm in no danger—mayn't we—mayn't we salute sometimes, it will seem infinitely more natural.

sp.speaker: MARC.
sp.p: Never; such an attempt would make me sly off at once.

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p:
Well, you must be lady governess in this business.—I'll
go home now, and fret madam, about her young mother-in-law—By'e sweeting!

sp.speaker: MARC.
sp.p: By'e charmer!

sp.speaker: CAES.
sp.p: Oh, bless its pretty eyes!

sp.speaker: MARC.
sp.p: Bless its pretty spectacles! ha, ha, ha! enter into a league with a cross old father against a daughter! why how could he suspect me capable of so much treachery? I cou'd not answer it to my conscience. No, no I'll acquaint Donna Olivia with the plot; and, as in duty bound, we'll turn our arms against Don Caesar.

div2.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: LAURA.
sp.p: WELL, Pedro! hast thou seen Don Florio?

sp.speaker: PED.
sp.p: Yes, Donna.

sp.speaker: LAU.
sp.p: How did he look when he read my letter?

sp.speaker: PED.
sp.p: Mortal well, I never see'd him look better—he'd got on a new cloak, and a—

sp.speaker: LAU.
sp.p: Pho, blockhead! did he look pleas'd? did he kiss my name? did he press the billet to his bosom with all the warmth of love?

sp.speaker: PED.
sp.p: No, he didn't warm it that way; but he did another, for he put it into the fire.

sp.speaker: LAU.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: PED.
sp.p: Yes, and when I spoke, he started, for, I think, he had forgot that I was by—so, says he, go home and tell Donna Laura, I fly to her presence.
sp.stage: [She waves her hand for him to go.]

sp.speaker: LAU.
sp.p:
Is it possible? so contemptuously destroy the letter in which my whole heart overflow'd with tenderness? in which my upbraidings were mingled with the most passionate love! But why do I question it? has he ever treated me but with the most mortifying coldness, even whilst he pretended to be sensible of my charms? I feel myself on the brink of hatred; and, by all the
agonies I have felt, shou'd that passion be once rous'd.—Oh, how▪ idly I talk! he is here; his very voice pierces my heart. I dare not meet his eye thus discomposed.

div2.stage: Enter VICTORIA, (in Men's Cloaths) preceded by SANCHA.

sp.speaker: SANCH.
sp.p: I will inform my mistress that you are here, Don Florio, I thought she had been in this apartment.

sp.speaker: VICT.
